DOC.HEAD: Merrill Lynch Announces 300 Job Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Merrill Lynch & Co. said Tuesday it will cut about 300 jobs due to the sale of some clearing accounts from the company's Broadcort Capital Corp. subsidiary to Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Merrill Lynch said in a statement that the ``selected staff reductions'' would occur at Broadcort and related Merrill Lynch support areas over the next few months. Merrill Lynch said the agreement primarily would affect clearings of Broadcort's retail-oriented accounts. Clearings are the financial settlements of clients' securities transactions. Retail transactions account for about 45 percent of Broadcort's current business. Merrill spokesman Fred Yager declined to say how much of the retail activity was being transferred to Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette's Pershing Division. Yager said the changes are part of a restructuring announced by Merrill Lynch executives last month. The firm said it would realign or eliminate unprofitable areas, cut operating costs and trim investment bankers' bonuses because of a prolonged slump in the securities industry. Merrill Lynch, the nation's largest retail brokerage with 40,500 employees and 12,600 brokers worldwide, also said layoffs were likely but it did not give an estimate. Yager said the job cuts related to the Broadcort transaction would be achieved through attrition and transfers. Broadcort, formed in 1977, is a unit of Merrill Lynch's Professional Securities Services Group in the firm's equity markets division.
